Libraries
```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)

install.packages("WikidataQueryServiceR")
install.packages("rJava")
install.packages("rcdk")
install.packages("pls")
install.packages("gplots")

library("WikidataQueryServiceR")
library("rJava")
library("rcdk")
library("pls")
```

Query for the alkanes and their properties

```{r}
results_table<-results[,c(2,3,5,6)]

#change everything to Kelvin

results_kelvin<-results_table

Celsius<-results_table[which(results_table$bpUnitLabel=='degree Celsius'),2]
results_kelvin[which(results_table$bpUnitLabel=='degree Celsius'),2]<-Celsius+273.15

Farent<-results_table[which(results_table$bpUnitLabel=='degree Fahrenheit'),2]
results_kelvin[which(results_table$bpUnitLabel=='degree Fahrenheit'),2]<-(Farent ??? 32) * 5/9 + 273.15
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
